title: Practice is key to stacking rocks - Taranaki's pro rock-stacker says
text:
Practice is key to stacking rocks - Taranaki's pro rock-stacker says JEREMY WILKINSON Last updated 16:44, February 1 2017 ANDY JACKSON/Stuff.co.nz 
Daniel Morgan says stacking rocks helps calm his mind. 
For most people precise and delicate tasks that require hours of attention like stacking rocks could be very stressful, but for Daniel Morgan it's an exercise in meditation. 
"I just get in a state where I'm completely in the moment and absorbed with what I'm doing," the New Plymouth rock-stacker and artist said. 
"Some of these pieces take hours while some I can put together fairly quickly." ANDY JACKSON/Fairfax NZ 
When he's stacking Morgan said everything else is tuned out. 
Morgan has been stacking rocks in physics-defying ways for years, leaving his works along New Plymouth's coastal walkway or even in the middle of streams.

He said he and a friend started out at the Stoney River "just trying to get out in nature" and stacking basic sculptures. ANDY JACKSON/Fairfax NZ 
Morgan likes to make his sculptures in the Huatoki Stream for the peace and quiet but also so the public can still see them. 
"From there it turned into a bit more of a thing and eventually evolved into what it is now," he said. 
"I find it calming, I deal with a bit of anxiety from time to time and this helps me relax. Being out in nature, having something singular to focus on with absolute concentration is very peaceful." 
He said the best things about his works are that they're temporary and that as soon as he lets his hands go from the rocks they cease to become his. ANDY JACKSON/Fairfax NZ 
Some take him hours others can be put together "fairly quickly". 
"I just want people to get enjoyment out of seeing these, if that involves them throwing rocks at them that's fine, at least they're having fun." 
As for the technique Morgan said it was "easy to explain but hard to do". 
"It's all about counterbalance, you try and figure out a rough line where you want the rocks to sit and try and keep to that. ANDY JACKSON/Fairfax NZ 
Morgan said it's all about just getting out into nature. 
"My advice for anyone starting out would be to start off small and work your way up. 
"It just takes tons and tons of practice." 
It wasn't until recently that Morgan bought himself a pair of fishing waders, before that he said his feet would go purple standing in rivers for hours on end. ANDY JACKSON/Fairfax NZ 
Practice is key to getting as good as Morgan. 
"It's partly to protect my feet as well, you wouldn't believe the stuff that ends up in our rivers. 
"Lots of glass but also laptops, phones, iPads and all other kinds fo junk." ANDY JACKSON/Fairfax NZ 
Fishing waders have helped him lift his game. - Stuff
